channel.title: Glossary on CyS3cGuy
channel.description: Recent content in Glossary on CyS3cGuy

item.title: Escape Character
item.description: Escaping a character means adding a special prefix (often a backslash ) before a character to indicate that it should be treated differently than it normally would be in a given context, such as in a string, a regular expression, in URL, or in HTML. For example, in URL, “%” is treated as a special character, because if the URL has “%”, it will do an operation called URL encoding. Examples of URL encoding:

item.title: Directory
item.description: Directory is a IT-term for “Folder”. If I say “Navigate to DirA directory”, in GUI-based term, it means that I’m asking you to double click on the folder named “DirA” and open it.

item.title: Terminal
item.description: Think of Terminal / Command Prompt as the black interface that allow users to input command and interact with the Operating System. Using Terminal / Command Prompt allows the users to interact with computer via shell interface. Most users are not accustomed in using the shell interface provided via Terminal / Command Prompt due to our daily lives are so deeply intertwined with the GUI-based Windows OS, i.e. mouse click, double mouse click, up/down/left/right arrow key, drag & drop, moving mouse cursor.

item.title: SSH
item.description: SSH stands for Secure Shell. Think of a physical computer which is online but you do not have access to the computer physically (We call that a remote computer). SSH provides a secure way to connect to that remote computer via a Terminal / Command prompt and interacting with the shell interface rather than the usual GUI-based interface.
